Question: Which committee was entrusted with the task of preparing a draft of the new Constitution?
B): Expert Committee on the Financial Provisions of the Union Constitution
Answer: D) Drafting Committee
Explanation: Among all the committees of the Constituent Assembly, the most important committee was the Drafting Committee set up on August 29, 1947. It was this committee that was entrusted with the task of preparing a draft of the new Constitution.

Question: What is the procedure for impeachment of Governors as per the Constitution of India?
A): It is not mentioned in the Constitution of India
B): It is the same as the procedure for impeachment of the President, mutatis mutandis
C): The Governor can be removed by the Chief Minister of the state
D): The Governor can be removed by the Prime Minister of India
Answer: B) It is the same as the procedure for impeachment of the President, mutatis mutandis
Explanation: As per paragraph 10, the procedure laid down for impeachment of President, mutatis mutandis can be made applicable for impeachment of Governors as well.

Question: Which article of the Indian Constitution guarantees six rights to all citizens?
Answer: C) Article 19
Explanation: Article 19 guarantees to all citizens the six rights. These are: (i) Right to freedom of speech and expression. (ii) Right to assemble peaceably and without arms. (iii) Right to form associations or unions or co-operative societies. (iv) Right to move freely throughout the territory of India. (v) Right to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India. (vi) Right to practice any profession or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.

Question: As per Article 324 of the Constitution, which of the following is true about the composition of the Election Commission?
A): The Election Commission consists of only the Chief Election Commissioner
B): The appointment of the Chief Election Commissioner and other election commissioners is made by the Prime Minister
C): The President may appoint regional commissioners to assist the Election Commission
D): The tenure of office of the election commissioners is determined by the Chief Election Commissioner
Answer: C) The President may appoint regional commissioners to assist the Election Commission
Explanation: As per Article 324 of the Constitution, the President may appoint after consultation with the election commission such regional commissioners as he may consider necessary to assist the election commission.

Question: What is the role of the finance commission in the financial position of the panchayats?
A): To levy, collect and appropriate taxes, duties, tolls and fees
B): To assign taxes, duties, tolls and fees levied and collected by the state government to the panchayats
C): To review the financial position of the panchayats and make recommendations to the Governor
D): To provide grants-in-aid to the panchayats from the consolidated fund of the state
Answer: C) To review the financial position of the panchayats and make recommendations to the Governor
Explanation: The finance commission is responsible for reviewing the financial position of the panchayats and making recommendations to the Governor on the distribution of taxes, duties, tolls and fees, grants-in-aid and measures needed to improve the financial position of the panchayats.

Question: Under which article of the Constitution can a high court issue writs including habeas corpus, mandamus, certiorari, prohibition and quo warranto for the enforcement of the fundamental rights of the citizens and for any other purpose?
Answer: B) Article 226
Explanation: Article 226 of the Constitution empowers a high court to issue writs including habeas corpus, mandamus, certiorari, prohibition and quo warranto for the enforcement of the fundamental rights of the citizens and for any other purpose.

Question: What are the limitations placed on the Attorney General of India?
A): He cannot appear in any court outside of India
B): He cannot advise or hold a brief against the Government of India
C): He cannot speak in the proceedings of the Houses of Parliament
Answer: B) He cannot advise or hold a brief against the Government of India
Explanation: The Attorney General of India is restricted from advising or holding a brief against the Government of India, among other limitations.

Question: According to the observations made by the Commission on the working of the Constitution from 1950 to 2000, which of the following is true about India's democratic base?
A): It has been weakened over time
C): It has stabilized as a working federal polity
Answer: C) It has stabilized as a working federal polity
Explanation: The observations made by the Commission on the working of the Constitution from 1950 to 2000 state that India’s democratic base has stabilized as a working federal polity.

Question: Under which article is the President authorised to provide special responsibility to the Governor of Maharashtra and Gujarat?
Answer: B) Article 371
Explanation: Under Article 371, the President is authorised to provide that the Governor of Maharashtra and that of Gujarat would have special responsibility.

Question: What is the doctrine of 'basic structure' of the Constitution?
A): The doctrine that Parliament is empowered to abridge or take away any of the Fundamental Rights
B): The doctrine that the constituent power of Parliament under Article 368 does not enable it to alter the 'basic structure' of the Constitution
C): The doctrine that there is no limitation on the constituent power of Parliament and no amendment can be questioned in any court on any ground including that of the contravention of any of the Fundamental Rights
D): The doctrine that the Supreme Court can invalidate any provision of the Constitution that affects the basic structure of the Constitution
Answer: B) The doctrine that the constituent power of Parliament under Article 368 does not enable it to alter the 'basic structure' of the Constitution
Explanation: The doctrine of basic structure of the Constitution was laid down by the Supreme Court in the Kesavananda Bharati case and reaffirmed in subsequent cases. It states that the constituent power of Parliament under Article 368 does not enable it to alter the 'basic structure' of the Constitution, which means that the Parliament cannot abridge or take away a Fundamental Right that forms a part of the 'basic structure' of the Constitution.

Question: Under what circumstances can the President proclaim a Financial Emergency?
A): If he is satisfied that the financial stability or credit of India or any part of its territory is threatened
B): If there is a shortage of essential commodities
C): If there is a threat of war with a neighboring country
D): If there is a natural disaster
Answer: A) If he is satisfied that the financial stability or credit of India or any part of its territory is threatened
Explanation: Article 360 empowers the president to proclaim a Financial Emergency if he is satisfied that a situation has arisen due to which the financial stability or credit of India or any part of its territory is threatened.

Question: Which doctrine is applied by the Supreme Court while interpreting the constitution to ensure that a law is not declared unconstitutional in its entirety?
Answer: C) Doctrine of Severability
Explanation: The Doctrine of Severability is applied by the Supreme Court while interpreting the constitution to ensure that a law is not declared unconstitutional in its entirety.

Question: What are the principles of voluntary formation, democratic member control, member economic participation and autonomous functioning that co-operative societies are based on, according to Part IX-B of the Indian Constitution?
A): Voluntary formation, democratic member control, member economic participation and state functioning
B): Voluntary formation, democratic state control, member economic participation and autonomous functioning
C): Voluntary formation, democratic member control, member economic participation and autonomous functioning
D): Voluntary formation, state member control, member economic participation and autonomous functioning
Answer: C) Voluntary formation, democratic member control, member economic participation and autonomous functioning
Explanation:
Part IX-B of the constitution contains the following provisions with respect to the cooperative societies:
Incorporation of Co-operative Societies: The state legislature may make provisions for the incorporation, regulation and winding-up of co-operative societies based on the principles of voluntary formation, democratic member control, member economic participation and autonomous functioning.

Question: As per the Constitution of India, which article deals with the establishment of National Commission for SCs and STs?
Answer: A) Article 338
Explanation: Article 338 deals with the establishment of National Commission for SCs and STs to investigate all matters relating to the constitutional safeguards for the SCs and to report to the President.

Question: What is the significance of fundamental duties according to the Indian Constitution?
A): They serve as a reminder to the citizens of their rights
B): They promote antinational and antisocial activities
C): They create a sense of discipline and commitment among citizens
D): They help in determining the constitutionality of a law
Answer: C) They create a sense of discipline and commitment among citizens
Explanation: Fundamental duties serve as a source of inspiration for the citizens and promote a sense of discipline and commitment among them. They create a feeling that the citizens are not mere spectators but active participants in the realization of national goals.

Question: What is the percentage of the poorest quintile's income in India?
Explanation: The poorest quintile has only 1.5 per cent of the country’s income.

Question: Which act was established to provide free and competent legal aid to the poor and to organise lok adalat for promoting equal justice?
Answer: C) The Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987
Explanation: The Legal Services Authorities Act (1987) has established a nation-wide network to provide free and competent legal aid to the poor and to organise lok adalat for promoting equal justice.

Question: What is the mission of CBI?
A): To enhance inter-state and international cooperation in law enforcement
B): To combat corruption in public life and curbing economic and violent crimes
C): To create a healthy work environment that encourages teambuilding
D): To uphold human rights and protect the environment, arts, antiques and heritage of our civilization
Answer: B) To combat corruption in public life and curbing economic and violent crimes through meticulous investigation and prosecution
Explanation: As per the given paragraph, the mission of CBI is to combat corruption in public life and curbing economic and violent crimes through meticulous investigation and prosecution.

Question: What is the doctrine of 'basic structure' of the Constitution and when was it established?
A): It is the power of Parliament to abridge or take away any of the Fundamental Rights.
B): It is the power of Parliament to amend the Constitution without any limitations.
C): It is the limitation on the constituent power of Parliament to alter the basic structure of the Constitution.
D): It is the power of the Supreme Court to invalidate any provision of the Constitution.
Answer: C) It is the limitation on the constituent power of Parliament to alter the basic structure of the Constitution.
Explanation: The doctrine of 'basic structure' of the Constitution was established in the Kesavananda Bharati case in 1973 by the Supreme Court. It stated that the constituent power of Parliament under Article 368 does not enable it to alter the 'basic structure' of the Constitution, which means that the Parliament cannot abridge or take away a Fundamental Right that forms a part of the 'basic structure' of the Constitution.

Question: What is the recommendation given in the paragraph for bringing greater accountability in fiscal legislations?
A): An annual assessment by the government
B): An annual assessment by a private body
C): An annual assessment by an independent body
Answer: C) An annual assessment by an independent body
Explanation: To bring greater accountability, all fiscal legislations should provide for an annual assessment by an independent body and the reports of these bodies should be laid in both Houses of Parliament/state legislature.
